Award.AbstractNarration:
Translational data science is an emerging field that applies data science principles, techniques and technologies to scientific, economic, and societal challenges that hold the promise of having an important national impact. In order to understand the important shifts in how data is used and applied to many aspects of daily life, it is important to effectively apply these principles and tools within our diverse research environments to successfully address these challenges for the benefit of human and societal welfare. This workshop will build upon discussions initiated at two previous NSF-funded workshops on translational data science and focus on the challenges of engaging in translational data science; challenges related to technical issues; and challenges related to organizational and cultural change. The perspectives and insights shared from industry, government, nonprofits, and academia, coupled with discussions focused on actionable challenges and measurable outcomes, will serve to advance the field of data science as well as related fields and application areas. This workshop will provide mechanisms for identifying high-priority topics and high-impact opportunities for future research, training, and collaboration.

The objectives of this workshop will be to facilitate the growth of the emerging community related to translational data science; strengthen existing connections; and engage the academic community with the perspectives and insights available from industrial and public sector partners. Another objective will be to discuss and align different views about the challenges that are most important in translational data science, and clearly identify opportunities and high priority areas to guide research and funding. By convening a diverse community of stakeholders who can contribute to the strategic development of a translational data science roadmap and ecosystem, this workshop will build and strengthen connections across sectors. Another theme of the workshop will be "responsible data science", to explore how foundational issues in responsible use of data can be translated to data science practice, with a focus here on public sector use cases. The workshop will also discuss open issues related to if and how the notion of translational data science fundamentally changes how data science is practiced and taught, and the applied and basic research and pedagogical issues that may arise in this context.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary objectives of this workshop were to grow and strengthen the emerging community around translational data science, and expose the academic community to perspectives and insights available from partners in other sectors. A critical secondary objective was to discuss and align different views about challenges in translational data science, and clearly identify opportunities and high priority areas to guide research and funding. The organizing committee convened representatives from industry, nonprofits, city government and academia to capture approaches that may improve outcomes for translational data science. 

 

The group documented challenges under three broad areas and proposed approaches to each. Funding streams and planning recommendations were also discussed. The group agreed that responsible data science approaches should be foundational to translational data science, and incorporated them throughout the discussions.

 

Challenges:

 

  • Organizational: Collaboration across sectors and domains was highlighted as a key challenge. Proposed approaches included:

    •  Building cross-sector teams to develop new methods, design and improve systems, apply outcomes to interesting and relevant applications, and effectively communicate translational results. 

    • Creating of a data clearinghouse, which might include a dedicated metadata staff, in response to current hesitations to share data due to the effort involved in appropriately annotating it. 

    • Ensuring inclusion of all relevant stakeholders to translational data science. Some of these include, but are not limited to: data collectors, database administrators and ETL experts, data scientists, developers, legal and ethical experts, domain experts, program administrators, academics, and neutral arbiters. 

  • Technical: Although some conceptual level toolkits in this broad space may exist (e.g., the beta version of the Ethics and Algorithms Toolkit put together by the Center for Government), actual automated tools to check for bias and other ethical issues through each stage of the data science lifecycle (e.g., data collection, data aggregation) are lacking. The discussions were characterized by substantial enthusiasm for the creation and prototyping of relevant frameworks and tools and consideration of the best path toward implementation, being mindful of ethical issues that arise with automation. Ideas for specific toolkits ranged from relatively lightweight and inexpensive (e.g., creating detailed checklists to assess for bias and data quality throughout the data lifecycle) to involved projects that would take more resources over a longer period (e.g., building software analysis tools to track data quality in an entirely or mostly automated way). For cases in which data sharing might not be appropriate or feasible, it would be useful to develop sophisticated ways to build synthetic datasets.

  • Cultural: The group discussed how to foster broader participation in the translational data science ecosystem. This group would not only include data scientists, but also users of data science products and the stakeholder community that could be impacted by the solutions produced. Recommendations included:

  • Video: The creation of a series of videos that teach data literacy in an engaging, accessible manner - e.g., ?How to understand voting data.? 

  • Frameworks: The creation of templates for incorporating data science into various domain classes -  e.g., how to incorporate data science into writing. 

  • Training: The establishment of 1-2 year apprentice programs within companies or government, allowing people with no formal data science background to move into data science jobs, leveraging their previous skills and knowledge. 

  • Novel Approaches: Enabling data science technology transfer in non-traditional ways, e.g., engaging data science students through a junior VC funding program.

 

Funding streams and planning recommendations:

 

The group identified potential streams of funding and representative projects to further the potential of translational data science. These included NSF?s Harnessing the Data Revolution Big Idea, particularly in potential collaboration with researchers working in the area of Convergence Acceleration, where the domain- and sector-crossing focus of translational data science can provide tools and perspectives necessary for its development. 

 

Planning recommendations that emerged from the workshop included:

 

  • Curriculum development for translational data science;

  • Tool and system production employing principles in translational data science;

  • ?Lighthouse projects? (large-scale data-driven innovation and demonstration projects that create superior visibility, awareness and impact) demonstrating translational data science success and viability;

  • Competitive ?puzzle? or ?challenge? models where potential researchers and software developers demonstrate capacity and commitment to solving defined problems of importance as part of the funding application process (in the mode of recent NIH/NCATS initiatives); and 

  • Directed investment in expanding translational data science capacity.

 

By convening a diverse community of stakeholders who can contribute to the strategic development of a TDS roadmap and ecosystem, this workshop built and strengthened connections across sectors. The perspectives and insights shared from industry, government, nonprofits, and academia, coupled with discussions focused on actionable challenges and outcomes, will serve to advance translational data science and many associated fields and application areas.  The workshop provided a mechanism for identifying high-priority topics and high-impact opportunities for future research, training, and collaboration.
